tossups.answer: The Marriage of Figaro [accept Le nozze di Figaro] <GA> Bonuses

parts: Name this freeform style of virtuosic music that is typically lively and energetic. A famous Rachmaninoff rhapsody takes a theme from one of these works.
This composer began his Capriccio Italien with a bugle call, which was inspired by a similar call made by the Corazziere that he heard during his stay in Italy.
This Russian composer titled both the first and the third movement “Alborada” in his Capriccio Espagnol. He also wrote the symphonic suite Scheherazade and The Flight of the Bumblebee.
Name this city which titles a Quartet consisting of the novels Justine, Balthazar, Mountolive, and Clea. This city was famous for a lighthouse.
The Alexandria Quartet is a tetralogy written by this British ex-pat. This author also wrote The Avignon Quintet, which includes Monsieur, or The Prince of Darkness.
This other Egyptian city is the setting for a trilogy by Naguib Mahfouz which includes Palace Walk. Mona Prince’s My Name Is Revolution was inspired by events in this city’s Tahrir Square.

answers: zero-sum game [accept strictly competitive game; prompt on competitive game] <CL>
parts: Identify this mathematical field which deals with logical decision making. One situation analyzed in this field is the prisoner’s dilemma.
In the prisoner’s dilemma, this state occurs when each player turns the other in. In this state, players cannot improve their own outcomes by unilaterally changing their strategies.
Game theory originally addressed this type of game, exemplified by cutting a cake. The minimax theorem can be used to solve this type of game.

answers: Persephone [accept Kore, do not accept “Proserpina” or “Proserpine”]
Demeter [accept Sito or Thesmophoros, do not accept “Ceres”] <RY>
parts: Commonly known as Thallo, Auxo and Carpo, these goddesses of the seasons are sisters of the Fates. Their duties include guarding the gates of Olympus and driving the motion of the constellations at night.
After Theseus and Pirithous (“PIE-roth-us”) attempted to kidnap this Greek goddess of spring from the Underworld, they were restrained on rocks at the edge of Tartarus.

This Greek goddess of grain, Persephone’s mother, causes the changes of the seasons. When Persephone lives with her, it is spring and summer, and when Persephone leaves for the underworld, it becomes fall and winter.

answers: inverse square law [accept negative second power or power of negative two; accept square root]
Paul (Adrien Maurice) Dirac [accept Dirac delta function; accept Dirac equation] <CL>
parts: Identify this vector field which describes the electromagnetic force that would be exerted on a test particle at a given location.
The electric field for a point charge can be calculated using a corollary of Coulomb’s law, which states that the source charge and radial distance have this relationship.
The density of a point charge, on the other hand, is represented by a function named for this man, who also names an equation which predicted the existence of antimatter.

answers: slaves [accept word forms such as slavery]
parts: Name this economic system in which Africa, the Americas, and Europe exchanged goods via trade on the Atlantic Ocean. Its name is derived from the shape that the routes form on a map.

This human good formed Africa’s primary export to the Americas. The trade in this type of good was banned by the British in 1807, and the Royal Navy is generally credited with the successful eradication of the Atlantic trade in this good.

This term is applied to the section of the triangle trade that consisted of slaves being shipped from Africa to the Americas. This journey was notoriously dangerous, with mortality rates generally estimated at 15%.
Name this dance form whose technique includes five “positions” as well as movements called pliés and pirouettes.

This man revived interest in ballet in France at the turn of the twentieth century with the founding of the Ballets Russes, which was based in Paris. This man also commissioned ballets by composers Richard Strauss and Erik Satie.

Through Diaghilev’s management of the Ballets Russes, choreographer George Balanchine brought interest to the United States, and later worked with this American dancer on ballets such as Episodes. This dancer also commissioned and choreographed Aaron Copland’s ballet Appalachian Spring.

Name this 1992 to 1995 ethnic conflict in the Balkans that included the first example of genocide in Europe since the end of the Second World War. This war is named after the primarily-Muslim group that was targeted, and it included the Srebrenica Massacre.
This group’s leaders perpetrated the Bosnian genocide. The country that takes its name from this ethnic group has its capital at Belgrade.
This Serbian President during the Bosnian War resigned during the 2000 Bulldozer Revolution after attempting to resist giving power to to Vojislav Kostunica.

answers: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders
parts: Name this series of manuals that has been published by the American Psychiatric Association since 1952. The fifth edition introduced the new sub-category of “motor disorders,” and replaced the term “mental retardation” with “intellectual disability.”

This developmental disorder, characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, was deleted in the DSM-5 and its symptoms folded into “Autism Spectrum Disorder.” It is named for an Austrian pediatrician.
A new chapter in the DSM-5 on these disorders includes excoriation, or skin-picking, disorders, and hoarding disorders. These disorders are often abbreviated as “OCD.”

answers: the Buddenbrook family [accept Buddenbrooks; prompt on Johann’s family]
Death in Venice [accept Der Tod in Venedig]
parts: Identify this family, four generations of which appear in a 1901 novel inspired by its author’s own. This family of Lübeck merchants includes Antonie, Clara, and Thomas.
In this novella by the author of Buddenbrooks, Gustav von Aschenbach becomes obsessed with the boy Tadzio and repeatedly runs into red-headed strangers.
This German author of Buddenbrooks and Death in Venice also retold Genesis stories in Joseph and His Brothers and described Hans Castorp’s journey to visit Joachim Ziemssen in The Magic Mountain.
Name this Prophet of Islam whom one is not supposed to draw.
This woman was the mother of the loser at the Battle of Karbala, Husayn ibn Ali, by her husband, Ali. She was also the namesake of a much later caliphate that was absorbed by Saladin in 1171.

The Battle of Karbala was part of the second of the conflicts described by this Arabic word. The first of these conflicts was a battle for control of the Islamic world that ended in the overthrow of the Rashidun Caliphate and establishment of the Umayyad Caliphate.
Name this term that refers to one or more forms of an element in the same state. These entities arise due to different structural modifications.
This element has numerous solid allotropes that all revert to the same 4-molecule form when melted in the liquid state. This nonmetal in the nitrogen group contains 5 valence electrons.
This allotrope of phosphorus exists in two different crystalline forms. This highly flammable and toxic compound turns yellow in the presence of light.

answers: Josef Vissarionovich Stalin [accept Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili; accept Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili]
parts: Name this Soviet leader who was in power from 1953 to 1964. He attracted international attention for banging his shoe on a table at the UN during the Cuban Missile Crisis.
This predecessor of Khrushchev and target of the “Secret Speech” led the Soviet Union during the Second World War.
This short-lived later Soviet ruler led the KGB for fifteen years, and was succeeded by Konstantin Chernenko as General Secretary after his 1984 death.

Name this concept that is often defined as the capacity of acting to fulfill one’s desires. The existence of the “free” variety of this concept has long been a topic of debate among scholars and theologians.
This German philosopher is most famous for writing The World as Will and Representation, in which he posited that aesthetic pleasure creates temporary escape from the Will.

Schopenhauer also wrote the 1851 essay “On [these people]”. The authors of the 2005 book Philosophers Behaving Badly wrote that Schopenhauer was among the most prejudiced philosopher against these people in the Western canon.

answers: simple squamous cells [accept simple squamous epithelium]
parts: Name this pair of organs directly below the ribcage. They take in oxygen and give off carbon dioxide through diffusion.
Alveoli of the lungs are formed of this thinnest, most permeable type of tissue. This type of tissue contains a single layer of flat cells.
The trachea branches into these two tubes, which provide the air supply for the two lungs. They branch off and become thinner and thinner, eventually turning into alveoli.

answers: Jim [do not accept or prompt on “James” or “Jimmy”]
Hank Morgan [accept either; accept The Boss; do not accept or prompt on “The Yankee” because it was mentioned in the question] <CL>
parts: This Twain character’s Adventures are described in one book, and in another, he spies some body snatchers and searches for buried treasure with his best friend, Tom Sawyer.

In The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Huck escapes down the Mississippi River with a slave with this first name. “The Tall Soldier” in The Red Badge of Courage also has this first name, followed by the last name Conklin.
This Twain character is the protagonist of a book in which a head injury causes him to wake up in 6th century England, A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur’s Court.

answers: Hermes with the Infant Dionysus [accept any clear knowledge equivalent that includes both underlined portions; accept Hermes of Olympia; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this sculpture of a baby sitting on the arm of a young man, who rests on a tree trunk covered by a mantle.
Hermes with the Infant Dionysus was created by this ancient artist from Athens. Other mythological works by this artist include Aphrodite of Cnidus and Apollo Sauroktonos.

Praxiteles left behind several of these body parts from statues, including two named for Leconfield and Aberdeen. In Rembrandt’s Aristotle Contemplating a Bust of Homer, the central figure lays a hand on this body part, and an apple obscuring part of this body part in Magritte’s Son of Man.

answers: Mexico [accept Republic of Mexico; accept Mexican Empire]
Don Miguel Gregorio Antonio Ignacio Hidalgo-Costilla y Gallaga Mandarte Villaseñor
parts: Name this North American country that contains the states of Sonora and Baja California. It is directly to the south of the United States.
This Catholic priest and early Mexican revolutionary issued the Grito de Dolores, but was executed in the aftermath of his defeat at the Battle of Calderon Bridge.
This liberal Zapotec-descended five-term Mexican president led resistance to the French-backed government of Emperor Maximilian I in the 1860s. He has often been called Mexico’s Abraham Lincoln.

answers: Stan Musial [prompt on Stan the Man] <SB>
parts: Griffey mainly played for this Pacific Northwest team, whose current stars include Robinson Canó and Félix Hernández.
From 2001 until 2012, Seattle’s right fielder was this Japanese superstar, who broke the single-season hits record with 262 in 2004.

The greatest left-handed outfielder born on November 21st in Donora, Pennsylvania is this 1950s player for the St. Louis Cardinals. This Hall of Famer had 3,630 career hits; 1,815 at home, and 1,815 on the road.

answers: Alfred, Lord Tennyson [accept Alfred Tennyson; accept First Baron Tennyson]
parts: Name this poem, in which the speaker says, “Cannon to right of them / Cannon to left of them / Cannon in front of them / Volley’d and thunder’d.”
“The Charge of the Light Brigade” is by this British author. He wrote, “I hope to see my Pilot face to face” in the poem “Crossing the Bar,” and also wrote the poem “Ulysses.”
Tennyson’s “The Charge of the Light Brigade” opens by repeating this three-word phrase three times. After that, he wrote, “[O]nward / All in the valley of Death / Rode the six hundred.”
Name this general type of force, also called an inertial force, that acts on all masses whose motion is described in a non-inertial reference frame.

This fictitious force acts on objects that are in motion relative to a rotating reference frame. This phenomenon results in cyclones spinning counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere but clockwise in the Southern.
This other fictitious force also acts in a rotating reference frame and is directed away from the axis of rotation.
